dos: Drop, Cover, and Hold On if you're indoors during shaking
Stay away from windows, mirrors, and heavy objects that could fall
If outdoors, move to an open area away from buildings, trees, and power lines
After shaking stops, check for injuries and damage
Listen to emergency broadcasts for instructions
Be prepared for aftershocks
Turn off gas if you smell it or suspect a leak
Use stairs, not elevators when evacuating buildings
Keep emergency supplies ready: water, food, first aid kit, flashlight
Have a family communication plan
donts: Don't run outside during shaking - most injuries occur from falling objects
Don't use elevators during or after an earthquake
Don't light matches or use lighters if gas leak is suspected
Don't use your phone except for emergencies - keep lines clear
Don't spread or believe rumors - rely on official sources only
Don't enter damaged buildings
Don't touch downed power lines or objects touching them
Don't use your vehicle unless absolutely necessary
Don't panic - stay calm and think clearly
Don't stand near unstable structures or debris

dos: Move to higher ground immediately if flooding is expected
Evacuate if told to do so by authorities
Keep important documents in waterproof containers
Turn off utilities at main switches if instructed
Bring outdoor belongings inside or tie them down
Fill bathtubs and sinks with clean water as a reserve
Monitor weather updates and emergency broadcasts
Stay out of floodwater - it may be contaminated or electrically charged
Use a stick to check ground firmness if you must walk in water
Wear protective clothing and boots if exposed to floodwater
donts: Don't walk, swim, or drive through floodwater - just 6 inches can knock you down
Don't drive around barricades - they're there for your safety
Don't touch electrical equipment if wet or standing in water
Don't eat food that has been in contact with floodwater
Don't return home until authorities say it's safe
Don't ignore evacuation orders
Don't underestimate the power of moving water
Don't let children play in or near floodwater
Don't drink floodwater or use it for washing without purification
Don't camp or park near streams or rivers during heavy rainfall

dos: Alert others immediately by shouting 'Fire!' and activating fire alarms
Call emergency services (911) as soon as possible
Evacuate immediately - leave belongings behind
Feel doors before opening - if hot, use another escape route
Crawl low under smoke to breathe cleaner air
Close doors behind you to slow fire spread
Use stairs, never elevators during a fire
Go to your designated meeting point once outside
If clothes catch fire: Stop, Drop, and Roll
Use a fire extinguisher only if you're trained and the fire is small
donts: Don't go back inside for any reason once you've evacuated
Don't try to fight a large fire yourself
Don't open doors without checking if they're hot first
Don't use elevators during a fire
Don't hide - evacuate immediately
Don't breathe smoke - cover nose and mouth with cloth if possible
Don't run if clothing catches fire - Stop, Drop, and Roll
Don't waste time gathering belongings
Don't break windows unless absolutely necessary for escape
Don't use water on electrical or grease fires

dos: Evacuate if ordered by authorities
Board up windows or close storm shutters
Bring outdoor furniture and decorations inside
Stock up on emergency supplies: water, food, batteries, medications
Fill your vehicle's gas tank
Charge all electronic devices
Know your evacuation route and have a plan
Stay indoors during the hurricane in a secure room away from windows
Monitor weather updates continuously
Have cash on hand - ATMs may not work after the storm
donts: Don't ignore evacuation orders
Don't use candles during the storm - use flashlights instead
Don't go outside during the 'eye' of the hurricane - winds will resume
Don't use generators indoors - they produce deadly carbon monoxide
Don't tape windows in an 'X' pattern - this doesn't prevent breakage
Don't wait until the last minute to prepare
Don't drive through standing or moving water
Don't touch downed power lines
Don't use the phone except for emergencies
Don't open refrigerator or freezer unnecessarily during power outage

dos: Seek shelter immediately in a basement or interior room on the lowest floor
Get under sturdy furniture and protect your head and neck with your arms
Stay away from windows, doors, and outside walls
In a vehicle or mobile home, get out and seek shelter in a building or lie flat in a ditch
Listen to NOAA Weather Radio or local news for updates
Have a tornado emergency kit ready
Wear sturdy shoes and protective clothing
Keep a battery-powered radio and flashlight handy
Practice tornado drills with your family
Know the signs: dark greenish sky, large hail, loud roar
donts: Don't stay in a mobile home during a tornado
Don't try to outrun a tornado in your vehicle in urban areas
Don't take shelter under highway overpasses
Don't open windows - this wastes valuable time
Don't stay in large open rooms like gyms or auditoriums
Don't ignore tornado warnings
Don't go outside to watch or photograph the tornado
Don't use elevators during a tornado warning
Don't wait to see the tornado before taking shelter
Don't leave your shelter until the danger has passed and authorities give all-clear

dos: Stay calm and assess the situation
Follow instructions from emergency personnel
Keep emergency contact numbers accessible
Have a family emergency plan and practice it
Maintain a disaster supply kit with 3-day supplies
Know the emergency procedures for your workplace and children's schools
Keep important documents in a waterproof, fireproof container
Have adequate insurance coverage
Learn basic first aid and CPR
Stay informed through official emergency channels
donts: Don't panic - fear clouds judgment
Don't spread unverified information or rumors
Don't ignore warning signs or alerts
Don't assume someone else will help - take responsibility
Don't venture into dangerous areas out of curiosity
Don't use resources wastefully - they may be scarce
Don't separate from your family without a communication plan
Don't post your exact location on social media during active disasters
Don't ignore the needs of vulnerable people (elderly, children, disabled)
Don't give up - remain hopeful and resilient
